dt: {bc}a picture with a motto or set of verses intended as a moral lesson
{bc}an object or the figure of an object symbolizing and suggesting another object or an idea
{bc}a symbolic object used as a heraldic device
{bc}a device, symbol, or figure adopted and used as an identifying mark

et: borrowed from Middle French & New Latin; Middle French {it}embleme{/it} "symbolic image typically accompanied by a motto and a verse exposition (books of which constituted a literary genre in the Renaissance)," borrowed from New Latin {it}emblēmat-, emblēma,{/it} going back to Latin, "inlaid pavement, inlaid relief on the inside of a metal bowl or other vessel," borrowed from Greek {it}emblēmat-, émblēma{/it} "something inserted (as a shaft into a spearhead), relief ornament decorating silver plate," from {it}emblē-,{/it} stem in noun derivation of {it}embállein{/it} "to drop or place in, throw into, insert," from {it}em-,{/it} variant of {it}en-{/it} {et_link|en-:2|en-:2} before a labial + {it}bállein{/it} "to reach by throwing, cast, strike, put, place" {ma}{mat|devil:1|}{/ma}

The use of Latin {it}emblēma{/it} in reference to a combination of symbolic image and text is apparently owed to the Italian jurist and scholar Andrea Anciato (1492-1550), who gave rise to the emblem book genre with his {it}Emblematum liber{/it} (Augsburg, 1531). The semantic gap between the literal meaning of the word and Alciati's use of it has yet to be fully explained. Pace the comments by John F. Moffitt (Andrea Alciati, {it}A Book of Emblems: The Emblematum Liber in Latin and English{/it} [Jefferson, NC: 2004], introduction, p. 7), neither Cicero, Quintilian, nor Coelius Rodiginus provide any definite basis for the meaning given {it}emblēma{/it} by Alciati.
shortdef: a picture with a motto or set of verses intended as a moral lesson
an object or the figure of an object symbolizing and suggesting another object or an idea
a symbolic object used as a heraldic device
